Technical Assistance Report
 
 
 
Project Number: 54158-002 
Transactional Technical Assistance (TRTA) 
March 2020 
 
 
 
Republic of the Philippines: Implementing a Rapid 
Emergency Supplies Provision (RESP) Assistance 
to Design a Sustainable Solution for COVID-19 
Impact Areas in the National Capital Region, 
Through Public Private Collaboration  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Access to Information 
Policy.

(as of 26 March 2020)

CIHH  –  COVID-19-impacted households  
COVID-19  –  coronavirus disease 2019 
DILG  –  Department of the Interior and Local Government 
DND  –  Department of National Defense

    DSWD  –  Department of Social Welfare and Development 
GOP  –  Government of the Philippines  
NCR  –  National Capital Region  
RESP  –  Rapid Emergency Supplies Provision

I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The Government of the Philippines (GOP) has requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  to  provide  support  for  developing  a  longer-term  funding  mechanism  to  combat  the 
coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic caused by the novel coronavirus. In this regard, 
GOP and ADB have initiated discussions on various approaches to respond especially to the 
social impact of the pandemic, including establishing a fund for COVID-19 response projects. The 
project would aim to impact through an accelerated response all aspects of the value chain for 
combating COVID-19. The outcome would be a platform with clear principles for leveraging public 
funds to catalyze funds from private and philanthropic sources for a deeper and wider impact on 
vulnerable  households  in  the  Philippines.  Outputs  would  include  establishing  institutional 
structure and mechanism for a COVID-19 fund, principles for innovative finance usage, and 
households targeting methodology, and  providing financing for eligible subprojects.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
2.  The proposed Rapid Emergency Supplies Provision (RESP) technical assistance (TA) will 
support the GOP in developing a mechanism and principles for establishing a fund to combat the 
COVID-19 pandemic. A series of activities to be implemented under the proposed TA will provide 
inputs for the structure of the fund. The GOP is addressing the urgent and still-unfolding crisis 
resulting from the spread of COVID-19 in the National Capital Region (NCR) and broader Luzon 
area, where a large majority of the country’s 636 COVID-19 cases (as of 25 March 2020) reside. 
The  social  and  economic  impact  of  COVID-19  containment  through  enhanced  community 
quarantine is felt most acutely in these areas of the country. 
 
3.  The TA will implement activities aimed at accelerating the immediate amelioration of the 
direct and indirect effects of COVID-19 through socio-economic relief to the poorest and most 
vulnerable segments of the population in the NCR, by facilitating equitable access to food and 
essential supplies likely to prevent the spread of COVID-19 across the NCR and the Philippines. 
These activities will directly contribute towards the design of a longer-term fund to respond to the 
social and economic impacts of COVID-19 epidemic. The TA will implement a scalable public-
private-philanthropic-collaboration to provide food and essential supplies to the poorest and most 
vulnerable households to improve the health, living conditions, and resilience of the most COVID-
19-impacted-households (CIHH) in the NCR and broader Luzon area. The TA proposal was 
discussed between ADB and GOP as part of ADB’s overall response to contain impact of COVID-
19 on 20 March 2020. The Department of Finance (DOF) has confirmed the proposal and 
implementation arrangements. The TA is being identified as the “Food by Friday” program in GOP 
and ADB external disseminations. 
 
4.  TA Role. In its support to the GOP in designing and implementing a response for the 
COVID-19 pandemic in the NCR, the TA will cover both emergency response phase activities and 
formulation of further prevention phase activities, including provision of immediate and short-term 
critical components (such as food and essential supplies), partnerships with private entities for 
enhanced  emergency  responses,  and  supporting  national  capacities  for  emergency 
preparedness and mitigation, in line with ADB’s disaster and emergency assistance policy.1 
 
 
1 ADB. 2015. Disaster and Emergency Assistance. Operations Manual. OM D7. Manila.

2 
5.  Emergency Response Rationale. The epidemic has erupted at a staggering pace and 
scale, with 636 confirmed cases and 38 deaths (as of 25 March 2020) in the country, with over 
32 of these deaths between 12 and 25 March 2020.2 The scale of the disaster is deepening with 
the number of medical personnel either placed under quarantine with suspected exposure to 
COVID-19  or  passing  away  rapidly  escalating.  An  “enhanced  community  quarantine”  and 
mandated temporary closure of non-essential shops and businesses have been put in effect on 
the entire Luzon island, which includes the NCR.  
 
6.  Quarantine restrictions have already begun to impact especially those households already 
at poverty level thresholds as well as informal, self-employed, seasonal, and contractual workers, 
with a three-fold and interconnected impact: (i) catastrophic loss in income (inability to access 
daily wage activities), (ii) closures of retail outlets reducing the ability to purchase essential 
supplies (even if there were some savings), and (iii) limited supply of goods for the most 
vulnerable and weakest segments of the population with panic buying by the more economically 
prosperous. Further, for older age groups or people with pre-existing health issues, who are at 
major risk from COVID-19, there is a heightened need for isolation restricting the use of cash or 
voucher schemes. There is thus a need to provide, in the immediate term, at least basic food and 
hygiene items to ensure the health of such households, allow for self-isolation to prevent further 
spread of COVID-19, and reduce socio-economic tensions or possibly even riots.   
 
7.  Targeting Rationale. Over 75% of confirmed cases of COVID-19 are in the NCR. With 
over 12 million population, the NCR is the largest contributor to the country’s GDP (36%). With a 
dense population spread (over 20,000 persons per square kilometer), it is also at the greatest 
threat – already in evidence - from an exponential increase in COVID-19 cases, threatening also 
the health, financial, and economic well-being of the nation. The most vulnerable households and 
informal workers in the NCR is estimated to be around 756,000 households, or 3.8 million people, 
based on existing social programs.3 The Department of Social Welfare and Development (DSWD) 
has identified around 100,000 households as highly vulnerable and commenced provision of food 
and essential items to some of these households under its Pesos 1.3 billion quick response fund. 
The GOP has also begun measures (including the creating of an Inter-Agency Task Force) to 
provide essential items, faster procurement of medical and emergency supplies, and acceleration 
of release of donated relief goods. A private sector initiative, Project Ugnayan, is also aiming to 
distribute  Pesos  1,000  food  vouchers  to  poorer  communities  in  the  NCR.  In  coordination 
discussions with these initiatives, ADB estimates that at least 55,000 CIHH are likely to be in 
urgent need of bridging support over an immediate term of between 2-8 weeks until other 
measures kick in. Providing essential food items to these 55,000 CIHH alone for a 3-month period 
would require almost $25 million. Geographical selection of barangays/cities to identify CIHH 
households will be done during the preliminary phase of the proposed TA, as part of output 1. 
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
8.  Output 1: Rapid Emergency Supplies Provision (RESP) mechanism established. 
The TA will rapidly mobilize staff across ADB, under the “One ADB” spirit, and experts who will 
work with executing agency staff to design the mechanics for the RESP, including (i) CIHH 
targeting approaches for CIHH in the NCR, (ii) composition and costing for essential food supplies 
packages per CIHH per month for an initial 2-8 week period, (iii) procurement and contracting 
processes for acquiring such supplies, (iv) linkages with local governments and barangays for 
 
2 Department of Health, GOP and World Health Organization online statistics, 22 March 2020. 
3 Including NCR population under the 4Ps program, indigent elderly people under the Listahan program, 
and 334,000 household-equivalents (covering 50% of the estimated informal workers in NCR).

3 
effective  CIHH  identification  and  disbursement  support,  and  (v)  monitoring  and  evaluation 
systems.   
 
9.  Output  2:  Public-Philanthropic-Partnerships’  Platform  established.  The  TA  will 
establish partnerships to leverage funds and core strengths of philanthropic-private entities in the 
Philippines and across the world to help the poor and vulnerable in the NCR.  Specifically, the TA 
will support the GOP in (i) expanding the pool of philanthropic-private sector entities willing to 
support the RESP (e.g. large manufacturing business, logistics entities, philanthropic funds, and 
business associations),  (ii)  establishing contributions as either funds,4 in-kind goods (for the 
essential  food  supplies  packages)  or  services  (logistics,  distribution,  etc.),  (iii)  developing 
mechanisms with good governance practices for the deployment of, monitoring and reporting on, 
such  contributions,  and  (iv)  development  and  finalization  of  collaboration  agreements  with 
finalized participants. Appropriate integrity due diligence principles and practices will be followed 
as required before accepting contributions (cash or in-kind) from third parties. 
 
10.  Output 3: Essential Food Supplies Provided to CIHH. TA funds will be utilized to (i) 
procure and deliver essential food supplies packages5 for the pilot targeted CIHH in the NCR over 
a 2-8 week period (targeting of CIHH will be led by DSWD supported by ADB experts to ensure 
no overlaps and coordination with other measures), (ii) procure additional distribution services to 
identified CIHH, and (iii) procure consulting and technology services to provide coordination and 
management information systems. The scale of activities will depend on both costing aspects as 
well as collaborations with philanthropic-private sector entities. 
  
11.  Output 4: Proposal for a Fund for COVID-19. The TA will engage consulting services to 
develop a possible ensuing project, conceptually entitled, Fund for COVID-19. This fund will aim 
to provide a longer-term proposal for the GOP to consider for meeting any widening spread of the 
COVID-19 pandemic and build on the learnings from the implementation activities in outputs 1 to 
3 above, while also exploring use of innovative financing instruments. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $5,555,555, $5,000,000 of which will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-others) of ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of 
counterpart staff, office accommodation, secretarial assistance, local transportation, and other in-
kind contributions (use of warehouse facilities for collection, packaging, distribution as well as 
provision of personal protective equipment to all distribution teams). Any TA scope expansion 
through partnerships between GOP, ADB, and philanthropic-private institutions will be explored 
 
4 All options for funds inclusion in the TA will be explored.  One option is for third parties to contribute cash 
directly to ADB to administer in support of the TA. ADB’s Controllers’ Department has set up separate 
bank accounts to receive financial contributions in pesos and United States dollars from third parties.  
Other options include transfer of funds to a third party to administer on behalf of the Department of 
Finance (the executing agency) and ADB. Appropriate due diligence and documentation will be prepared 
to operationalize funding options.    
5 Current DSWD estimates for a basic pack of critical food items for emergency support: a household of 5 
people, in a 2-day period: 6 kgs of rice, 4 tins tuna flakes, 5 coffee sachets, 2 tins sardines, 4 tins corned 
beef, and 5 sachets powdered cereals. Under the Disaster and Emergency Assistance Policy, paragraph 
98, technical assistance for disaster and emergency can provide critical components of early emergency 
assistance, including acquisition of critical supplies for basic services. 2004. Disaster and Emergency 
Assistance Policy. Manila.

4 
for increased impact.6 The government was informed that approval of the TA does not commit 
ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  ADB will administer the TA on behalf of the GOP. Southeast Asia Regional Department 
will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  consultants.  ADB  may  also  utilize  consultants  already 
engaged under existing TA projects to support this TA. The executing agency (EA) will be the 
Department of Finance (DOF) with two implementing agencies (IAs):  DSWD and Department of 
the Interior and Local Government (DILG). The strengths of each IA will be combined seamlessly 
for implementation, including identifying essential food needs and qualities (DSWD) and assisting 
in targeting and distribution (DILG). DOF will ensure overall coordination, including with ADB. and 
effective use of public and private contributions (i.e. ensuring no overlaps between initiatives).  
 
14.  A steering group established by the GOP, the Inter-Agency Task Force (IATF) on COVID-
19, will provide policy guidance and oversight on TA implementation. The IATF comprises officials 
from the DOF, DSWD, DILG, and Department of National Defense (DND). Three subgroups within 
the IATF will provide guidance on 3 separate aspects: finance, procurement, and logistics. 
 
15.  Procurement of goods and services (for output 3) under the TA will be undertaken by ADB, 
coordinating with and receiving endorsements from the EA on all aspects (including composition 
of essential items, and targeting CIHH). All goods procured by ADB will be delivered directly (by 
suppliers) to specified warehouse facility locations (under the DND) as instructed by the EA. The 
designated government agency under DND will be responsible to keep such goods under its 
custody until delivery to beneficiaries. The designated government agency will be responsible for 
the quality assurance and inspection certification of all goods before distribution. Warehousing, 
packaging, and distribution of goods procured will be managed by the DND and the Armed Forces 
of the Philippines all the way to impacted Barangays; Barangay captains will also be supported in 
delivering to individual CIHH. As ADB will procure the goods and services (for output 3), direct 
payment method will be used to make payments to suppliers upon receipt by ADB of EA verified 
reports from (i) deliveries to warehouse, (ii) deliveries to Barangay nodes, and (iii) deliveries to 
individual CIHH with (iv) ADB’s coordinator (consultant) facilitating these reports as well as 
providing third party verification.  
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

6 It is estimated that a $5 million TA could provide support to 55,000 CIHH for a 14-16 days period with the 
basic pack of critical food items. This could be substantially extended with private sector contributions, 
with an aimed for additional $15 million (in cash or kind) contributions. This is set as an aspirational target, 
given  the  large-scale  income  and  livelihood  losses  from  the  much-needed  enhanced  quarantine 
measures. ADB will make every effort to leverage as much resources as possible.

17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated TA administration instructions and/or 
staff instructions.7 
 
18.  TA  implementation  will  be  carried  out  through  national  and  international  individual 
consultants  (up  to  6  person-months  each),  recruited  following  individual  selection  method, 
international or local advertisement, based on TA requirements. Consultants engaged in ADB-
financed  projects  for  similar  services  may  either  be  extended  or  selected  through  direct 
contracting, subject to satisfactory performance. This arrangement will provide an efficient way to 
recruit consultants under the circumstances. Consulting services will commence in March 2020, 
to be rendered full time and/or intermittently until October 2021. 
 
19.  ADB’s procurement (goods and services under Output 3). ADB will undertake the 
procurement following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated TA administration instructions and/or staff instructions. 
 
E.  Governance 
 
20.  TA implementation will be supported by consultants who will coordinate between ADB and 
relevant government agencies. Any future collaboration opportunities with private sector entities 
will be discussed with GOP for governance and coordination approaches.   
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $5,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Republic  of  the  Philippines  for  Implementing  a  Rapid  Emergency  Supplies  Provision 
Assistance to Design a Sustainable Solution for COVID-19 Impacted Areas in the National Capital 
Region, Through Public Private Collaboration, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
7  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).
